chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Typecasting is the process of converting a variable from one data type to another.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have various functions to convert a value or variable to a string, an integer,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: a float, or a Boolean.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now you actually could get the data type of a variable or a value by using the type function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then pass in a value or variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: However, when I run this, there's no output.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I need a print statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will print what is returned by the type function, get the type of our name variable,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: then print it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So our name variable is a string, STR.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our age variable is an integer and int.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: GPA is a float.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is student is a Boolean.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using these type cast functions, we can convert from one data type to another.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's how.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's start with something simple.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's convert our GPA to an integer.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Currently, it's a float.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will reassign GPA, use the int function to type cast to an integer, then pass in my GPA.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: At the end, we will print our GPA.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we type cast 3.2 to a whole integer, what would the result be?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A whole integer of three.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We truncate the decimal portion.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's convert our age to a floating point number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will reassign our variable of age, use the type cast function of float, then insert our age variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print our age variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And it should be a floating point number 25.0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now we'll cover strings.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's type cast our age to be a string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Age equals call the type cast function of string, STR, pass in our age variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So the result is still going to appear the same.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: However, it's a string, not an integer.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And to prove that, I will enclose my age variable with the type function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The type of variable age is a string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It would be the same as if we're taking this number and enclosing it within quotes.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So this would make a difference because let's say that I add one to age, age plus equals one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, we would get a type error.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Can only concatenate strings, not integers, to a string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: However, if I were to add a string of one to the end, we would be using string concatenation.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's say it's my birthday and I add one to 25.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, since we're working with strings now, the result would be 251.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I am 251 years old.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So strings and numbers behave differently.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With numbers, we can use them within arithmetic expressions.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Strings, not so much.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will take our name variable and typecast it to a Boolean.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Name equals call the type cast function of Boole, pass in our name variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This has an interesting result.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I'm going to print name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Booleans are either true or false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I typecast my string of text into a Boolean, that gives me true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now, it really doesn't matter what I write here.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I were to change my name to a single character such as B, this would still be true.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If our string variable was empty, there were no characters within it, that would actually give us false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We could use this to check to see if somebody enters in their name or not.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If somebody types in their name, then we typecast it to a Boolean.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If somebody skips entering in their name, that would return false.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We could reprompt the user to enter in their name again.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Art of everybody. So that is typecasting.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It is the process of converting a variable from one data type to another.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is especially useful with handling user input.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Because user input is always a string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There may be at times where we want to convert it to an integer, a float or a Boolean.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And well, everybody, that is typecasting in Python.
